elements.content: Six new 3D metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) Cd2(3,4-PDC)2(μ2-hmt)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O)2 (JUC-65), Zn4(3,4-PDC)4(μ2-hmt)(H2O)6·(DMA)4(H2O)5 (JUC-66), Cd2(3,4-PDC)2(bipy)2(H2O)2·(DMA)3(H2O)4 (JUC-67), Cd2(3,4-PDC)2(bipy)(DMF)(H2O)·(H2O)2 (JUC-68), Mn2(3,4-PDC)2(μ2-hmt)(H2O)2 (JUC-69), and Zn8(3,4-PDC)8(bipy)3(DMA)2·(DMA)8(H2O)8 (JUC-70) (3,4-H2PDC = pyridine-3,4-dicarboxylic acid, hmt = hexamethylenetramine, bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine, DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide, DMA = N,N′-dimethylacetamide, and JUC = Jilin University China) have been synthesized via heterocoordination of unsymmetrical 3,4-H2PDC and transition metal ions (Cd2+, Zn2+, or Mn2+) to construct corrugated layers pillared by hmt or bipy ligands, which form various sizes and shapes of channels. Remarkably, from the topological point of view, JUC-65−68 exhibit three undocumented types of (3,4)-connected networks, JUC-69 exhibits a rare (4,5)-connected network, and JUC-70 possesses an unprecedented (3,4,5)-connected network. In addition, methanol adsorption isotherms of the activated JUC-65 and JUC-67 reveal type I behavior with approximately 87.7 mg/g and 124.8 mg/g at room temperature, respectively.

elements.content: Crystalline metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have been paid extensive attention in the past decade due to their fascinating topologies and various potential applications, such as adsorption, separation, and catalysis. Unlike traditional porous zeolite materials whose pores are confined by tetrahedral oxide skeletons and thus are difficult to tune, the modular construction of MOFs allows their pore size and shape to be systematically tuned by the judicious choice of metal-containing secondary building units (SBUs), bridging organic linkers, or both. In particular, the pillared frameworks recently have attracted widespread research interest because of their dynamic features and functional properties in selective adsorption, hydrogen storage, and chiral catalysis. Studies demonstrate that the “pillaring” strategy is a rational and effective approach for the construction of three-dimensional (3D) metal−organic open frameworks, using appropriate spacer ligands acting as pillars to connect with well-defined two-dimensional (2D) layers. Furthermore, channel shape and dimension in pillared MOFs can be controlled via the choice of the pillaring ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystalline metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been paid extensive attention in the past decade due to their fascinating topologies and various potential applications, such as adsorption, separation, and catalysis. Unlike traditional porous zeolite materials whose pores are confined by tetrahedral oxide skeletons and thus are difficult to tune, the modular construction of MOFs allows their pore size and shape to be systematically tuned by the judicious choice of metal-containing secondary building units (SBUs), bridging organic linkers, or both. In particular, the pillared frameworks recently have attracted widespread research interest because of their dynamic features and functional properties in selective adsorption, hydrogen storage, and chiral catalysis. Studies demonstrate that the "pillaring" strategy is a rational and effective approach for the construction of three-dimensional (3D) metal-organic open frameworks, using appropriate spacer ligands acting as pillars to connect with well-defined two-dimensional (2D) layers. Furthermore, channel shape and dimension in pillared MOFs can be controlled via the choice of the pillaring ligand.

elements.content: Meanwhile recent reviews on the framework topologies and other geometrical characteristics of network solids reveal that the analysis and direction of network topologies is an important aspect of the metal−organic frameworks, and the discovery of new topologies can be useful at the basic level in the crystal engineering of coordination networks. However, deviating from the so-called default structures to access more complex 3D structures with nondefault or novel topologies is a lasting challenge. Having studied the literature, we noticed that pyridine-3,4-dicarboxylic acid (3,4-H2PDC) is an excellent unsymmetrical building block with multiconnecting ability (possessing concurrently N- and O-coordinating moieties) in the construction of functional MOFs. In particular, the steric hindrance between the two proximal carboxyl groups leads to torsion of both carboxylate groups out of the plane, which will cause the carboxyl groups to connect metal ions in different directions and offer the potential to generate unique topological nets. Herein we elaborate on six novel 3D MOFs (JUC-65−70) with interesting topologies through heterocoordination of 3,4-H2PDC and transition metal ions (Cd2+, Zn2+, or Mn2+) to construct diversiform corrugated layers pillared by hexamethylenetramine (hmt) or 4,4′-bipyridine (bipy) ligands. In addition, the different adsorption capacities of methanol for the activated JUC-65 and JUC-67 have been observed owing to different pore size.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. TGA (thermal gravimetric analysis) was performed under an oxygen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å).

elements.content: A mixture of CdCl2·2.5H2O (30 mg, 0.13 mmol), 3,4-H2PDC (10 mg, 0.06 mmol) and hmt (10 mg, 0.07 mmol) was dissolved in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF, 5 mL), glycol (2 mL), and H2O (1 mL) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. elements.content: Diffraction intensities for JUC-65−70 were collected on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature by using the ω-scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the program SHELXTL. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles of complexes JUC-65−70 are listed in Tables S1−S6, respectively, in the . Crystal drawings were produced by Cerius2 software. CCDC 698316−698321 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. X-ray Crystallographic Study

The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the program SHELXTL. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles of complexes JUC-65-70 are listed in Tables S1-S6, respectively, in the . Crystal drawings were produced by Cerius2 software. CCDC 698316-698321 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, U.K.; fax (44) 1223-336-003; e-mail deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Methanol Sorption Isotherm

Methanol sorption isotherm studies were performed by measuring the increase in weight at equilibrium as a function of relative pressure. The weight of sample was measured by a Cahn 2000 electrobalance and the adsorbate (CH3OH) was added incrementally and manually.

elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of a metal chloride or nitrate salt (Cd2+, Zn2+, or Mn2+) with 3,4-PDC and an hmt or bipy organic linker in a mixture DMF/glycol/H2O, DMF/acetone/H2O, DMA/acetone/H2O, or DMF/(±)-2-methyl-1-butanol/H2O readily led to highly crystalline JUC-65−70 with diversiform structures. The pores of JUC-65−70 are filled with different solvents used in the synthesis reaction, which act as a template. Addition of a small amount of dilute nitric or muriatic acid favors the formation of larger crystals for structure characterization.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Solvothermal reactions of a metal chloride or nitrate salt (Cd2+, Zn2+, or Mn2+) with 3,4-PDC and an hmt or bipy organic linker in a mixture DMF/glycol/H2O, DMF/acetone/H2O, DMA/acetone/H2O, or DMF/(±)-2-methyl-1-butanol/H2O readily led to highly crystalline JUC-65-70 with diversiform structures. The pores of JUC-65-70 are filled with different solvents used in the synthesis reaction, which act as a template. Addition of a small amount of dilute nitric or muriatic acid favors the formation of larger crystals for structure characterization.

elements.content:
The structures of JUC-65−70 are all 3D non-interpenetrating frameworks where the 3,4-PDC ligands exhibit multiple coordination modes (Scheme ).

Cd<sub>2</sub>(3,4-PDC)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>2</sub>-hmt)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>·(DMF)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub> (JUC-65)

X-ray crystallography of JUC-65 reveals that each Cd2+ ion is seven-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of two chelating bidentate carboxylate groups from two crystallographically equivalent 3,4-PDC ligands in the equatorial plane, one aromatic nitrogen atom from another 3,4-PDC ligand, one nitrogen atom from the hmt ligand and one oxygen atom from a terminal H2O molecule, forming a slightly distorted monometallic {CdN2O5} pentagonal bipyramidal secondary building unit (SBU) (Figure a). Meanwhile, each independent divalent 3,4-PDC anion is coordinated to three Cd2+ metals using mode A. Carefully examining the structure of JUC-65, we find that first Cd2+ centers link 3,4-PDC ligands to form an infinite corrugated layer running along the bc plane (Figure b), which is a distorted 2D (6,3) honeycomb net. The independent hmt ligand acts as a pillar to support the adjacent corrugated layers generating a layer-pillared 3D structure with 1D hexagonal channels of approximately 6.5 × 11 Å2 viewed along the 001 direction (Figure d and Figure S1, ). After removal of DMF and H2O guest molecules, the effective free volume of JUC-65 is calculated by PLATON analysis as 42% (0.315 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume (1514.4 Å3 out of the 3608.0 Å3 per unit cell volume).

Cd2(3,4-PDC)2(μ2-hmt)(H2O)2⋅(DMF)2(H2O)2 (JUC-65)

X-ray crystallography of JUC-65 reveals that each Cd2+ ion is seven-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of two chelating bidentate carboxylate groups from two crystallographically equivalent 3,4-PDC ligands in the equatorial plane, one aromatic nitrogen atom from another 3,4-PDC ligand, one nitrogen atom from the hmt ligand and one oxygen atom from a terminal H2O molecule, forming a slightly distorted monometallic {CdN2O5} pentagonal bipyramidal secondary building unit (SBU) (Figure a). Meanwhile, each independent divalent 3,4-PDC anion is coordinated to three Cd2+ metals using mode A. Carefully examining the structure of JUC-65, we find that first Cd2+ centers link 3,4-PDC ligands to form an infinite corrugated layer running along the bc plane (Figure b), which is a distorted 2D (6,3) honeycomb net. The independent hmt ligand acts as a pillar to support the adjacent corrugated layers generating a layer-pillared 3D structure with 1D hexagonal channels of approximately 6.5 × 11 Å2 viewed along the 001 direction (Figure d and Figure S1, ). After removal of DMF and H2O guest molecules, the effective free volume of JUC-65 is calculated by PLATON analysis as 42% (0.315 cm3 g-1) of the crystal volume (1514.4 Å3 out of the 3608.0 Å3 per unit cell volume).

elements.content: Crystal structure of JUC-65: (a) view of the Cd2+ ion coordination environment; (b) an infinite 2D layer constructed from Cd2+ ions coordinated to 3,4-PDC ligands; (c) tetrahedral SBUs (cyan, {CdN2O5} units) and trigonal SBUs (red, 3,4-PDC ligands) form a (3,4)-connected network; (d) the 3D framework of JUC-65 formed by hmt supporting the corrugated layers viewed along the c axis with hexagonal channels. Color code: Cd, cyan; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. Hydrogen atoms and guest molecules have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: A better insight into the nature of JUC-65 can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (the Topos40 program is a powerful tool for the analysis, comparison, and design of network structures). As shown in Figure a, the monometallic {CdN2O5} SBU can simply be regarded as a quasi-tetrahedral 4-connected node since the terminal H2O molecules do not contribute to the network topology. Likewise, each 3,4-PDC ligand coordinated to three Cd2+ centers can act as a trigonal 3-connected node, and the pillaring N-donor μ2-hmt ligand ligating with two 4-connected {CdN2O5} units only serves as a bridged ligand. On the basis of the simplification principle, the resulting structure of JUC-65 is a binodal (3,4)-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is (63)(65·8) (the first symbol for 3-connected 3,4-PDC and the second one for 4-connected {CdN2O5} SBU), which is a hitherto undocumented (3,4)-connected topology structure (Figure c). Among the known (3,4)-connected nets in coordination polymers, the most symmetrical and important examples are Pt3O4, cubic C3N4, Cu15Si4, boracite, and the twisted boracite net, which are constructed by alternately linking the 3- and 4-connected nodes; however, not only are the 3- and 4-connected nodes alternately connected, but also the 4-connected nodes are directly associated together in the topology of JUC-65.

elements.content: X-ray crystallography of JUC-66 reveals that there are two distinct types of zinc ions and two unique 3,4-PDC ligands. The Zn1 center assumes a {Zn(1)N2O4} octahedral SBU with two oxygen atoms of two unidentate carboxylate groups and two aromatic nitrogen atoms coming from four independent 3,4-PDC ligands in the equatorial plane, completed by two terminal aqua molecules in the axial positions (Figure a). As shown in Figure b, the Zn2 center is five-coordinated by two oxygen atoms of one chelating bidentate carboxylate group and one oxygen atom of a unidentate carboxylate group from two different 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from the hmt ligand, and one terminal H2O molecule to form a slightly distorted {Zn(2)N1O4} pentahedral SBU. Different from JUC-65, where there is only one type of 3,4-PDC ligand, JUC-66 contains two types of 3,4-PDC ligands in coordination modes B and C. Both 3,4-PDC ligands are coordinated to three Zn2+ metal ions. We find that JUC-66 is also a layer-pillared 3D structure. First Zn1 and Zn2 centers link 3,4-PDC ligands to create an infinite corrugated layer running along the ac plane (Figure c). The independent hmt ligands act as pillars to extend the corrugated layers into a 3D structure with 2D intersected channels of 6.4 × 8.7 Å2 along the c axis and 6.6 × 7.5 Å2 along the a axis (Figure e and Figure S2, ). The effective free volume of JUC-66 is calculated by PLATON analysis as being 50.6% (0.478 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume (1836.9 Å3 out of the 3630.2 Å3 per unit cell volume) without DMA and H2O guest molecules.

Different from JUC-65, where there is only one type of 3,4-PDC ligand, JUC-66 contains two types of 3,4-PDC ligands in coordination modes B and C. Both 3,4-PDC ligands are coordinated to three Zn2+ metal ions. We find that JUC-66 is also a layer-pillared 3D structure. elements.content: Because the aqua molecules are disregarded from a topological perspective, the {Zn(1)N2O4} octahedral SBU and {Zn(2)N1O4} pentagonal SBU can simply be defined as a square-planar 4-connected node and a trigonal 3-connected node, respectively (Figure a,b). Meanwhile, 3,4-PDC ligating with three Zn2+ ions can act as a 3-connected node and the μ2-bridging hmt ligand can be considered as a linker between two 3-connected {Zn(2)N1O4} nodes. In this structure, the ratio of 3-connected 3,4-PDC, trigonal {Zn(2)N1O4} SBU, and square {Zn(1)N2O4} SBU is 2:1:1. The resulting structure of JUC-66 is a trinodal (3,4)-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is (63)2(6·102)(64·102) (the first symbol for 3-connected 3,4-PDC, the second one for 3-connected {Zn(2)N1O4} SBU, and the third one for 4-connected {Zn(1)N2O4} SBU), which is a new (3,4)-connected topology structure (Figure d). By contrast with the topology of JUC-65, in JUC-66 there are links between the 3- and 4-connected nodes, as well as between the 3-connected nodes.

elements.content: X-ray crystallography reveals that JUC-67 is also a layer-pillared 3D structure with a (3,4)-connected network. Each Cd2+ ion is six-coordinated by three carboxylic oxygen atoms and one aromatic nitrogen atom from three crystallographically equivalent 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from the bipy ligand, and one terminal H2O molecule, forming a {CdN2O4} octahedral SBU (Figure a). Each independent divalent 3,4-PDC anion is coordinated to three Cd2+ metals using mode B. As shown in Figure b, Cd2+ centers are connected by the 3,4-PDC ligands to give neutral corrugated layers with a (6,3) net running along the ab plane. These layers are then pillared by the bridging bipy ligands via the N−Cd bonds to generate a 3D structure with sector channels of 11.2 × 5.8 Å2 along the b axis and quadrangular channels 7.2 × 3.5 Å2 along the a axis (Figure d and Figure S3, ). Without DMA and H2O guest molecules, the effective free volume of JUC-67 is calculated by PLATON analysis as being 54.9% (0.518 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume (2553.0 Å3 out of the 4654.3 Å3 per unit cell volume).

elements.content: Topologically, if the 3,4-PDC units and {CdN2O4} SBUs are viewed to be the 3- and 4-connected nodes, respectively, then this framework becomes a binodal (3,4)-connected net built on trigonal organic spacers and tetrahedral metal centers (Figure c), and its Schläfli symbol is (63)(63·83) (the first symbol for 3-connected 3,4-PDC and the second one for 4-connected {CdN2O4} SBU), which is also an undocumented (3,4)-connected topology structure.

elements.content: X-ray crystallography of JUC-68 reveals that there are two distinct types of Cd2+ ions and two unique 3,4-PDC ligands. The Cd1 center has a distorted {Cd(1)N2O4} octahedral coordination sphere, with three oxygen atoms of one chelating bidentate and one unidentate carboxylate group from two independent 3,4-PDC ligands, and one bipy nitrogen donor in the equatorial plane. The coordination sphere is completed by one aromatic nitrogen atom from another 3,4-PDC ligand and one DMF molecule in the axial positions (Figure a). The Cd2 center is seven-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of two chelating bidentate carboxylate groups, one aromatic nitrogen atom from three different 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from the bipy ligand, and one H2O molecule to form a slightly distorted {Cd(2)N2O5} pentagonal bipyramidal SBU (Figure b). As shown in Figure c, Cd1 and Cd2 centers link with each other through two distinct types of 3,4-PDC ligands in modes A and B to form an arciform layer running along the ac plane. Then bipy ligands crosswise act as pillars to support the adjacent corrugated layers generating a 3D structure (Figure e).

The coordination sphere is completed by one aromatic nitrogen atom from another 3,4-PDC ligand and one DMF molecule in the axial positions (Figure a). The Cd2 center is seven-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of two chelating bidentate carboxylate groups, one aromatic nitrogen atom from three different 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from the bipy ligand, and one H2O molecule to form a slightly distorted {Cd(2)N2O5} pentagonal bipyramidal SBU (Figure b). As shown in Figure c, Cd1 and Cd2 centers link with each other through two distinct types of 3,4-PDC ligands in modes A and B to form an arciform layer running along the ac plane. elements.content: As discussed above, both {Cd(1)N2O4} and {Cd(2)N2O5} units can be regarded as tetrahedral 4-connected nodes for the topological description (Figure a,b), and 3,4-PDC ligands serve as 3-connected nodes. Therefore the resulting structure of JUC-68 is a binodal (3,4)-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is (63)(65·8) (the first symbol for 3-connected 3,4-PDC and the second one for 4-connected {Cd(1)N2O4} and {Cd(2)N2O5} SBUs), which is the same as that of JUC-65 (Figure d).

elements.content: In JUC-69, each Mn2+ ion adopts octahedral coordination geometry with three oxygen atoms from three independent 3,4-PDC ligands and one terminal H2O molecule in the equatorial plane and two nitrogen atoms from another 3,4-PDC and the hmt ligand in the axial direction to generate a {Mn1N2O4} SBU (Figure a). Different from foregoing compounds, the 3,4-PDC ligand adopts a unique coordination mode D connecting with four Mn centers in JUC-69. As shown in Figure b, {Mn1N2O4} SBUs link 3,4-PDC ligands to form an infinite corrugated layer running along the bc plane. Then the independent hmt ligand acts as a pillar to construct a layer-pillared 3D structure (Figure d).

elements.content: Topologically, we can consider each 3,4-PDC ligand and {Mn1N2O4} SBU to be 4- and 5-connected nodes, respectively. Therefore different from foregoing structures, the resulting structure of JUC-69 is a rare (4,5)-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is (44·62) (44·66) (the first symbol for 4-connected 3,4-PDC and the second one for 5-connected {Mn1N2O4} SBUs) (Figure c). Until now, only two 3D MOFs and one supramolecular MOF with (4,5)-connected nets were reported.

elements.content: Compared with JUC-65−69, the overall structure of JUC-70 is quite complicated with four distinct types of zinc ions. The Zn1 center is five-coordinated by two oxygen atoms and two aromatic nitrogen atoms coming from four independent 3,4-PDC ligands in the equatorial plane and one nitrogen donor of the bipy ligand in the axial position to form a slightly distorted {Zn(1)N3O2} pentahedral SBU (Figure a). The Zn2 center assumes a {Zn(2)N2O3} pentahedral SBU, which is the same as that of the Zn1 center except that bipy ligand is replaced by one terminal aqua molecule in the axial position (Figure b). The Zn3 center is also five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two different 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from bipy ligand and one DMA molecule forming another distorted {Zn(3)N1O4} pentahedral SBU (Figure c). The Zn4 center adopts tetrahedral coordination geometry with two oxygen atoms from two different 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from the bipy ligand, and one H2O to construct a {Zn(4)N1O3} SBU (Figure d). As shown in Figure a, Zn1, Zn2, Zn3, and Zn4 centers link with each other through two distinct types of 3,4-PDC in modes B and C to form a corrugated layer running along the ab plane. These layers are then pillared by bipy ligands between Zn1 centers, as well as between Zn3 and Zn4 centers, to generate a 3D structure with 2D intersected channels of 13.8 × 6.2 Å2 along the b axis and 7.1 × 6.5 Å2 along the a axis (Figure b and Figure S4, ). The effective free volume of JUC-70 is calculated by PLATON analysis as being 41.6% (0.37 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume (3141.5 Å3 out of the 7543.8 Å3 per unit cell volume) without DMA and H2O guest molecules.

The Zn4 center adopts tetrahedral coordination geometry with two oxygen atoms from two different 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from the bipy ligand, and one H2O to construct a {Zn(4)N1O3} SBU (Figure d). Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. Hydrogen atoms and guest molecules have been omitted for clarity.

Color code: Zn, green; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. Hydrogen atoms and guest molecules have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Because terminal molecules are disregarded from a topological perspective, the {Zn(1)N3O2}, {Zn(2)N2O3} {Zn(3)N1O4}, and {Zn(4)N1O3} SBUs can simply be defined as the 5-, 4-, and 3-connected nodes, and all crystallographically independent 3,4-PDC ligands can act as 3-connected nodes. Therefore the resulting structure of JUC-70 is a (3,4,5)-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is (6·8·10)(6·82)(63)4(64·102)(64·84·102) (the first symbol for 3-connected {Zn(4)N1O3} SBU, the second one for 3-connected {Zn(3)N1O4} SBU, the third one for 3-connected 3,4-PDC, the fourth one for 4-connected {Zn(2)N2O3} SBU, and the last one for 5-connected {Zn(1)N3O2} SBU) (Figure e). To the best of our knowledge, JUC-70 is the first example of a MOF with the unprecedented (3,4,5)-connected topology.

Therefore the resulting structure of JUC-70 is a (3,4,5)-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is (6⋅8⋅10)(6⋅82)(63)4(64⋅102)(64⋅84⋅102) (the first symbol for 3-connected {Zn(4)N1O3} SBU, the second one for 3-connected {Zn(3)N1O4} SBU, the third one for 3-connected 3,4-PDC, the fourth one for 4-connected {Zn(2)N2O3} SBU, and the last one for 5-connected {Zn(1)N3O2} SBU) (Figure e). To the best of our knowledge, JUC-70 is the first example of a MOF with the unprecedented (3,4,5)-connected topology.

elements.content: To study the adsorption properties, the methanol adsorption isotherms of JUC-65 and JUC-67 were measured at room temperature (ca. 293 K). Before the measurement, the samples of JUC-65 and JUC-67 were soaked in CH2Cl2 for 24 h then heated at 80 °C for 5 h to remove the guest solvent molecules. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of activated samples of JUC-65 and JUC-67 were identical to that calculated from the single-crystal structure, although the intensities become weak and the widths of some peaks show some differences, indicating that the departure of the guest molecules does not lead to a phase transformation (see the ). As shown in Figure , type I behavior is observed for the CH3OH adsorption isotherm of JUC-65 and JUC-67, which is characteristic of solids with micropores. The results indicate that incoming guests can move freely into the channels and the frameworks maintain their rigidity and porosity throughout the process. At saturation, the amounts adsorbed by JUC-65 and JUC-67 are about 87.7 and 124.8 mg/g, respectively, for CH3OH, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about 8 and 12 CH3OH molecules per unit cell. Additionally, we tried to measure the methanol adsorption of JUC-66 and JUC-70, which also have high pore volume. However, they could not maintain porosity upon guest solvent removal.
elements.clean_text:
Methanol Sorption Properties of JUC-65 and JUC-67

To study the adsorption properties, the methanol adsorption isotherms of JUC-65 and JUC-67 were measured at room temperature (ca. 293 K). Before the measurement, the samples of JUC-65 and JUC-67 were soaked in CH2Cl2 for 24 h then heated at 80 °C for 5 h to remove the guest solvent molecules. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of activated samples of JUC-65 and JUC-67 were identical to that calculated from the single-crystal structure, although the intensities become weak and the widths of some peaks show some differences, indicating that the departure of the guest molecules does not lead to a phase transformation (see the ). As shown in Figure , type I behavior is observed for the CH3OH adsorption isotherm of JUC-65 and JUC-67, which is characteristic of solids with micropores. The results indicate that incoming guests can move freely into the channels and the frameworks maintain their rigidity and porosity throughout the process. At saturation, the amounts adsorbed by JUC-65 and JUC-67 are about 87.7 and 124.8 mg/g, respectively, for CH3OH, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about 8 and 12 CH3OH molecules per unit cell. Additionally, we tried to measure the methanol adsorption of JUC-66 and JUC-70, which also have high pore volume. However, they could not maintain porosity upon guest solvent removal.

elements.content: Methanol adsorption isotherms for JUC-65 and JUC-67 at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 8  Methanol adsorption isotherms for JUC-65 and JUC-67 at room temperature.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized six novel 3D porous metal−organic frameworks with interesting topologies, JUC 65−68 based on three undocumented types of (3,4)-connected topology, JUC-69 described by rare (4,5)-connected topology, and JUC-70 exhibiting an unprecedented (3,4,5)-connected topology. The finding of these new topologies not only is useful at the basic level in the crystal engineering of coordination networks but also enriches the database of MOFs having mixed nodes. The comparison of these mixed node nets is summarized in Table . Meanwhile, methanol adsorption isotherms of JUC-65 and JUC-67 reveal type I behavior at approximately 87.7 and 124.8 mg/g at room temperature, respectively.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized six novel 3D porous metal-organic frameworks with interesting topologies, JUC 65-68 based on three undocumented types of (3,4)-connected topology, JUC-69 described by rare (4,5)-connected topology, and JUC-70 exhibiting an unprecedented (3,4,5)-connected topology. The finding of these new topologies not only is useful at the basic level in the crystal engineering of coordination networks but also enriches the database of MOFs having mixed nodes. The comparison of these mixed node nets is summarized in Table . Meanwhile, methanol adsorption isotherms of JUC-65 and JUC-67 reveal type I behavior at approximately 87.7 and 124.8 mg/g at room temperature, respectively.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of CdCl2·2.5H2O (30 mg, 0.13 mmol), 3,4-H2PDC (10 mg, 0.06 mmol) and hmt (10 mg, 0.07 mmol) was dissolved in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF, 5 mL), glycol (2 mL), and H2O (1 mL) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. HCl (2 M) was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at 60 °C for 3 days to give colorless block-shaped crystals. Yield: 68% (based on 3,4-H2PDC). Elemental Anal. Calcd C26H40N8O14Cd2 (913.22): C, 34.06; H, 4.40; N, 12.23. Found: C, 34.72; H, 4.32; N, 13.08.

Synthesis of Zn<sub>4</sub>(3,4-PDC)<sub>4</sub>(μ<sub>2</sub>-hmt)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>·(DMA)<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>5</sub> (JUC-66)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), 3,4-H2PDC (10 mg, 0.06 mmol), and hmt (10 mg, 0.07 mmol) was dissolved in N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 5 mL), acetone (2 mL), and H2O (1 mL) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. H2NO3 (2 M) was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at room temperature for several days to give colorless block-shaped crystals. Yield: 72% (based on 3,4-H2PDC). Elemental Anal. Calcd C50H82N12O31Zn4 (1608.78): C, 37.45; H, 5.16; N, 10.49. Found: C, 37.56; H, 5.62; N, 10.68.

Synthesis of Cd<sub>2</sub>(3,4-PDC)<sub>2</sub>(bipy)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>·(DMA)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub> (JUC-67)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), 3,4-H2PDC (10 mg, 0.06 mmol), and bipy (10 mg, 0.06 mmol) was dissolved in DMA (5 mL), acetone (2 mL), and H2O (1 mL) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. The mixture was left undisturbed at 60 °C for 3 days to give colorless crystals. Yield: 53% (based on 3,4-H2PDC). Elemental Anal. Calcd C48H61N9O17Cd2 (1236.86): C, 44.54; H, 4.96; N, 10.17. Found: C, 43.65; H, 5.21; N, 10.63.

Synthesis of Cd<sub>2</sub>(3,4-PDC)<sub>2</sub>(bipy)(DMF)(H<sub>2</sub>O)·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub> (JUC-68)

The procedure was the same as that for JUC-67 except that solvent DMA was replaced by DMF. Yield: 42% (based on 3,4-H2PDC). Elemental Anal. Calcd C27H27N5O12Cd2 (838.36): C, 38.53; H, 3.24; N, 8.33. Found: C, 39.12; H, 3.03; N, 8.28.

Synthesis of Mn<sub>2</sub>(3,4-PDC)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>2</sub>-hmt)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub> (JUC-69)

A mixture of MnCl2·4H2O (40 mg, 0.2 mmol), 3,4-H2PDC (10 mg, 0.06 mmol), and hmt (10 mg, 0.07 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (5 mL), (±)-2-methyl-1-butanol (2 mL), and H2O (1 mL) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. HCl (2 M) was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at 50 °C for several days to give pale yellow block-shaped crystals. Yield: 38% (based on 3,4-H2PDC). Elemental Anal. Calcd C20H22N6O10Mn2 (616.30): C, 38.96; H, 3.60; N, 13.64. Found: C, 39.15; H, 3.93; N, 12.68.

Synthesis of Zn<sub>8</sub>(3,4-PDC)<sub>8</sub>(bipy)<sub>3</sub>(DMA)<sub>2</sub>·(DMA)<sub>8</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub> (JUC-70)

The procedure was the same as that for JUC-67 except that Cd(NO3)2·4H2O was replaced by Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. The mixture was left undisturbed at room temperature for several days to give colorless block-shaped crystals. Yield: 69% (based on 3,4-H2PDC). Elemental Anal. Calcd C126H154N24O50Zn8 (3327.78): C, 45.62; H, 4.68; N, 10.14. Found: C, 45.83; H, 4.95; N, 11.28.

cln_elements.content:
X-ray crystallography reveals that JUC-67 is also a layer-pillared 3D structure with a (3,4)-connected network. Each Cd2+ ion is six-coordinated by three carboxylic oxygen atoms and one aromatic nitrogen atom from three crystallographically equivalent 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from the bipy ligand, and one terminal H2O molecule, forming a {CdN2O4} octahedral SBU (Figure a). Each independent divalent 3,4-PDC anion is coordinated to three Cd2+ metals using mode B. As shown in Figure b, Cd2+ centers are connected by the 3,4-PDC ligands to give neutral corrugated layers with a (6,3) net running along the ab plane. These layers are then pillared by the bridging bipy ligands via the N−Cd bonds to generate a 3D structure with sector channels of 11.2 × 5.8 Å2 along the b axis and quadrangular channels 7.2 × 3.5 Å2 along the a axis (Figure d and Figure S3, ). Without DMA and H2O guest molecules, the effective free volume of JUC-67 is calculated by PLATON analysis as being 54.9% (0.518 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume (2553.0 Å3 out of the 4654.3 Å3 per unit cell volume).

Zn<sub>8</sub>(3,4-PDC)<sub>8</sub>(bipy)<sub>3</sub>(DMA)<sub>2</sub>·(DMA)<sub>8</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub> (JUC-70)

 Compared with JUC-65−69, the overall structure of JUC-70 is quite complicated with four distinct types of zinc ions. The Zn1 center is five-coordinated by two oxygen atoms and two aromatic nitrogen atoms coming from four independent 3,4-PDC ligands in the equatorial plane and one nitrogen donor of the bipy ligand in the axial position to form a slightly distorted {Zn(1)N3O2} pentahedral SBU (Figure a). The Zn2 center assumes a {Zn(2)N2O3} pentahedral SBU, which is the same as that of the Zn1 center except that bipy ligand is replaced by one terminal aqua molecule in the axial position (Figure b). The Zn3 center is also five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two different 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from bipy ligand and one DMA molecule forming another distorted {Zn(3)N1O4} pentahedral SBU (Figure c). The Zn4 center adopts tetrahedral coordination geometry with two oxygen atoms from two different 3,4-PDC ligands, one nitrogen atom from the bipy ligand, and one H2O to construct a {Zn(4)N1O3} SBU (Figure d). As shown in Figure a, Zn1, Zn2, Zn3, and Zn4 centers link with each other through two distinct types of 3,4-PDC in modes B and C to form a corrugated layer running along the ab plane. These layers are then pillared by bipy ligands between Zn1 centers, as well as between Zn3 and Zn4 centers, to generate a 3D structure with 2D intersected channels of 13.8 × 6.2 Å2 along the b axis and 7.1 × 6.5 Å2 along the a axis (Figure b and Figure S4, ). The effective free volume of JUC-70 is calculated by PLATON analysis as being 41.6% (0.37 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume (3141.5 Å3 out of the 7543.8 Å3 per unit cell volume) without DMA and H2O guest molecules.

Methanol Sorption Properties of JUC-65 and JUC-67

To study the adsorption properties, the methanol adsorption isotherms of JUC-65 and JUC-67 were measured at room temperature (ca. 293 K). Before the measurement, the samples of JUC-65 and JUC-67 were soaked in CH2Cl2 for 24 h then heated at 80 °C for 5 h to remove the guest solvent molecules. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of activated samples of JUC-65 and JUC-67 were identical to that calculated from the single-crystal structure, although the intensities become weak and the widths of some peaks show some differences, indicating that the departure of the guest molecules does not lead to a phase transformation (see the ). As shown in Figure , type I behavior is observed for the CH3OH adsorption isotherm of JUC-65 and JUC-67, which is characteristic of solids with micropores. The results indicate that incoming guests can move freely into the channels and the frameworks maintain their rigidity and porosity throughout the process. At saturation, the amounts adsorbed by JUC-65 and JUC-67 are about 87.7 and 124.8 mg/g, respectively, for CH3OH, which are equivalent to the adsorption of about 8 and 12 CH3OH molecules per unit cell. Additionally, we tried to measure the methanol adsorption of JUC-66 and JUC-70, which also have high pore volume. However, they could not maintain porosity upon guest solvent removal.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of JUC-65: (a) view of the Cd2+ ion coordination environment; (b) an infinite 2D layer constructed from Cd2+ ions coordinated to 3,4-PDC ligands; (c) tetrahedral SBUs (cyan, {CdN2O5} units) and trigonal SBUs (red, 3,4-PDC ligands) form a (3,4)-connected network; (d) the 3D framework of JUC-65 formed by hmt supporting the corrugated layers viewed along the c axis with hexagonal channels. Color code: Cd, cyan; O, red; C, gray; N, blue. Hydrogen atoms and guest molecules have been omitted for clarity.
